awd_titl_txt: REU Site: MathILy Early Scholarly Training (MathILy-EST)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide three years of support for the REU Site program managed by Mathematical Staircase, Inc. to increase the depth of the mathematical workforce by offering a seven- to eight-week summer research program for students early in their mathematical careers.  Students belonging to groups underrepresented in mathematics are especially encouraged to apply.  This program will serve 6 early undergraduates each year and be run on the same campus as MathILy (serious Mathematics Infused with Levity), a 5-week very selective program of inquiry-based educational experiences for highly talented high-school students. MathILy-EST (MathILy Early Scholarly Training, pronounced "mathily-est") focuses on students who do not have other research opportunities, and will (a) train students in the mathematical thinking needed to conduct research, (b) increase participant persistence in the educational pipeline, (c) provide mentoring for students and early faculty research supervisors, and (d) provide cross-pollination with MathILy by proximity and by holding regular joint activities.  This REU Site program will give MathILy-EST participants early experience in active acquisition and creation of mathematical knowledge, which will in turn enable them to succeed in traditional mathematics classes. Training in software use, CV construction, presentation skills, and writing will give participants the informal knowledge and career skills needed to be competitive in the STEM workforce. Cross-fertilization between MathILy-EST participants and MathILy students and instructors will be significant: High-school participants in MathILy will see REU participants as mathematical role models and short-term future selves. They will see the processes of research happening around them and gain perspective on the mathematical enterprise. MathILy students and MathILy-EST participants alike will expand their networks beyond usual class cohorts to students of different ages.  The creation of peer networks along with mentoring of participants will increase their persistence in acquiring further mathematical education and research experience.  The existence of the MathILy-EST REU will prompt faculty discussion with first-year college students of summer opportunities that use their technical expertise, and thereby catalyze more fruitful advising for first-year college students within their home departments.

MathILy-EST participants will produce, present, and publish original research.  The program targets exceptional first-year college students, with second-year and entering college students also considered for participation.  The mathematical focus of MathILy-EST will change each year. The projects will be drawn from the following topics according to mentor availability: combinatorics of paperfolding, word length in the integers (additive number theory), free boundary problems (discrete PDEs), continuous-time game theory, and combinatorial representation theory.  MathILy-EST REU students will present their research progress to each other on a regular basis, with feedback provided on their research methods and presentation skills. Students will be asked to record work in writing (in LaTeX) weekly, to provide practice in writing formally and fodder for paper drafts once research has progressed to the point of publication.  At the end of the MathILy-EST REU program, the director will make plans with students, including sub-goals and timelines, for dissemination of their research results. This will include discussing potential local (MAA) and national (JMM) conference presentations and paper submissions. More details are available at http://www.mathily.org/mathilyest/index.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The MathILy-EST REU grant (NSF DMS-1851842, 2019--2022) supported 28 participants over four summers. (Cost savings from online operations during the global COVID-19 pandemic allowed the grant to partially support an additional year of the REU.) The participants worked together to produce research, presented their results at conferences, and submitted their work to undergraduate or research journals.  The four  research areas were combinatorics of rigid folding, geometric constraints on sorting, free boundary problems, and combinatorial representation theory.  MathILy-EST students wrote 8 research papers, three of which have been published.  One is currently under review, and four more are in progress toward publication; every participant is or will be a co-author on at least one paper.  

The participants attended presentations by visiting and staff mathematicians on a variety of mathematics topics, on mathematical career paths, and on choosing graduate schools. They learned to read mathematics papers and texts. MathILy-EST REU participants formed a peer network and joined the MathILy network and community; this, along with short- and long-term mentoring, has increased their persistence in acquiring further mathematical education and experience. Every participant made substantial gains in research skills over the MathILy-EST REU. All participants are therefore well prepared to excel in the mathematical sciences throughout college and beyond.

The participants were primarily first-year college students, with some second-year college students and two entering college students also participating. As hoped, the students were demographically diverse: half of the students identified as women; about one-fourth were Asian, one-seventh were Black, and about one-seventh were Latinx. A substantial fraction of the students identified as LGBT+.  Participant parents? highest educational attainments ranged from completing only elementary/middle school to having professional /doctoral degrees, with most categories in that range represented.  For the vast majority of the participants, this was their first opportunity to do research.

Mathematician observers uniformly rated the quality of the research and educational experiences, interactions between students and faculty, mentoring, and inclusivity as valuable or appropriate. A few visitor quotations: "The open discussion and support of the emotional and cultural change in doing research math was impressive."  "I was in awe by the work the students had done only two and half weeks after having started." "The environment was collaborative and inclusive, and the student presentations were clear and showed a strong command of and engagement with the material." "This program is awesome and is also one of a kind!" 

In followup surveys, participants rated MathILy-EST on the value of various research/professional skills, role models, mentoring, and networking; on average, participants rated MathILy-EST as valuable.  A few sample comments: "It increased my confidence in being able to pursue a career as a mathematician." "...we basically meet math people at all stages, which sheds light into what it's like to develop mathematical maturity." "I was certain I was going to continue into mathematics before the REU started, but now that it is over I am even more excited to do so."   

Finally, in longitudinal followup surveys, participants felt that participation in MathILy-EST positively influenced their career path or career.  Two quotations: "It has taught me to think about mathematics and professional careers in a different light."  "It gave me writing and research skills that I needed for my research this summer that we were expected to already have."
